articles.headline: Trump Veers From Party Line on Gun Control
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump said that people on the lists should be barred from buying firearms, putting him at odds with the National Rifle Association, which has endorsed him.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump said that people on the lists should be barred from buying firearms, putting him at odds with the National Rifle Association, which has endorsed him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump said Wednesday that people on the terror watch list should be barred from buying firearms, putting himself in the center of a gun-control debate in Congress revived by the worst mass shooting in United States history.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Visium Hedge Fund Managers Charged With Insider Trading
articles.snippet: Two Visium employees were accused of trading on confidential information provided by a former F.D.A. employee, who was also charged in the case.
articles.abstract: Two Visium employees were accused of trading on confidential information provided by a former F.D.A. employee, who was also charged in the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: A multibillion-dollar hedge fund focused on health care had an inside view of the drug approval process at the Food and Drug Administration through a former high-ranking official turned consultant.

articles.headline: Fed Holds Interest Rates Steady and Plans Slower Increases
articles.snippet: The central bank, which entered the year planning to raise rates four times, has scaled back those plans as economic growth has disappointed expectations.
articles.abstract: The central bank, which entered the year planning to raise rates four times, has scaled back those plans as economic growth has disappointed expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is struggling to adapt to an economy that refuses to boom.

articles.headline: Yes, Obamacare Premiums Are Going Up
articles.snippet: A new study shows health plans are asking for rate increases twice as high as last year’s. Two health reporters discuss what it means for the future.
articles.abstract: A new study shows health plans are asking for rate increases twice as high as last year’s. Two health reporters discuss what it means for the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Get ready for big increases in premiums under the Affordable Care Act. A new analysis from the Kaiser Family Foundation examined the most popular individual plans under the new health care law in 14 major cities around the country and found that insurers were asking for increases in 2017 that are twice as big as this year’s. There is wide variation, including some places where rates will go down, but the average requested increase is 10 percent.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz

articles.headline: Bypassing Private Equity to Get a Slice of the Big Deal
articles.snippet: So-called emerging buyers are becoming involved in deals on their own, without paying fees to private equity firms, but the risks are higher.
articles.abstract: So-called emerging buyers are becoming involved in deals on their own, without paying fees to private equity firms, but the risks are higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the buyers in some of the largest deals had come in three forms: private equity firms, corporations and public market investors.

articles.headline: The Fed Is Learning Just How Hard the Exit From Easy Money Will Be
articles.snippet: If markets could talk, they’d be saying to Janet Yellen: “We don’t think you’ll raise interest rates as much as you say you will.”
articles.abstract: If markets could talk, they’d be saying to Janet Yellen: “We don’t think you’ll raise interest rates as much as you say you will.”
articles.lead_paragraph: This is the buzz saw that Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, walked into as she addressed the news media — and by extension, every trading floor on earth — Wednesday afternoon.

articles.headline: Shanghai Disneyland Opens Amid Rain and Pageantry
articles.snippet: The first Disney park on the mainland, built for $5.5 billion, is being held up as nothing less than a historic symbol of United States-China relations.
articles.abstract: The first Disney park on the mainland, built for $5.5 billion, is being held up as nothing less than a historic symbol of United States-China relations.

articles.headline: The First Big Company to Say It’s Serving the Legal Marijuana Trade? Microsoft.
articles.snippet: As the marijuana industry grows inexorably more mainstream, an established company moves to enter the government compliance side of the business.
articles.abstract: As the marijuana industry grows inexorably more mainstream, an established company moves to enter the government compliance side of the business.
articles.lead_paragraph: As state after state has legalized marijuana in one way or another, big names in corporate America have stayed away entirely. Marijuana, after all, is still illegal, according to the federal government.
